title: Ticket #6971: Add timeouts to curl plugin
description:
While debugging some squid issues with Moate, we realized that the curl_plugin basically has no timeouts.

Basically, a particular CHTC-run squid had an issue where the server would allow clients to establish a TCP connection - but then one of the three worker processes would instantly lose track of the request. That means a request could be made from the curl_plugin but no response would be sent - ever!

There are two timeouts we should be setting:

  • Connection timeout: amount of time we're willing to wait for a TCP connection to be established. Useful when a firewall is silently dropping packets. Note this isn't the case described above.
  • Minimum speed timeout: useful to ensure the transfer is making forward progress.

(There is also an overall request timeout - but if the response size can vary from 1KB to 1GB, it's not clear what the value should be!)

The speed timeout has two settings: sampling interval and the minimum average speed. If the average transfer speed falls below the minimum over the course of a sample interval, then the transfer is killed.

For example, if the minimum average speed is set to 1KB/s and the sampling interval is set to 10 seconds, curl will kill the transfer if it does not receive at least 10KB over the course of 10 seconds.

There is an infinite amount of tuning that can be done to pick out the values for the minimum speed timeout. I propose we don't spend too much time here and set something very minimal, like 1KB/s and 30 seconds. It would solve the problem at hand (zero bytes are sent out over the course of hours) but not the case where the file transfer is so slow to be unusable.

Given that any default is likely wrong, we should additionally allow the user to override the values via an undocumented ClassAd setting. This would allow us to tune at CHTC without iterating over multiple versions of the code. If we decide this could be safely set by any user, we can document it.

When the timeout occurs, we should consider it a transient error (as it was in this case -- squid was actually only a blackhole for approximately 1/3 of the transfers).
remarks:
2019-May-06 12:29:40 by coatsworth:
CODE REVIEW

multifile_curl_plugin.cpp:

  • The call to ParseAds() should not happen in the constructor, just in case something goes wrong. We should explicitly call this somewhere else, probably in InitializeCurl() or even the main() function.
  • Lines 718 and 727: use safe_fopen_wrapper() instead of fopen().
  • The ParseAds() function makes me queasy for a bunch of reasons:
    • No comments and confusing logic flow. Why do you bail out of the function if ad is unset but not if ad2 is unset?
    • Why are you dynamically allocating the classad::ClassAd objects? This seems prone to leaks and doesn't offer any obvious advantages.
    • Similarly, shouldn't job_ad and machine_ad just be non-pointer std::string objects?
    • ad and ad2 should have more descriptive variable names.

file_transfer.cpp

  • Line 4816: This dprintf statement should happen inside each of the preceding if-statements (where we know the strings are non-empty), not outside.
  • Line 4923: same as above

file_transfer.h

  • Why does setRuntimeAds() have const std::string & input parameters, instead of just basic std::string objects?
